title: Tariffs, low stocks push aluminum prices higher in US
summary: US aluminum prices have surged 40% since tariffs were doubled to 50% in June 2024, reaching above $5,200 per metric ton. The Midwest aluminum premium hit a record high of 96 cents per pound ($2,116 per ton), up 65% since June, driven by tight global supplies and low US inventories that dropped from 750,000 to below 300,000 tons.

title: U.S. aluminum prices hit record highs amid tariffs, low supply
summary: Aluminum consumers in the United States are paying record prices significantly above what tariffs and transport costs alone would justify. London Metal Exchange prices have risen over 20% in the last 12 months to their highest level since April 2022, while the Midwest premium reached a record 96 cents per pound.

title: Aluminum prices soar on Trump tariffs, global shortages, and China
summary: American aluminum buyers are paying record spreads over global benchmarks amid Trump's 50% tariffs and worldwide shortages of 2 million tons per year. Import duties have nearly tripled from $560 per ton to over $1,400 since January, driving the record spike in the Midwest premium.

title: Aluminum prices top $3000 for the first time since 2022 as supply risks grow
summary: Global aluminum prices have surged to $3,000 per tonne, the highest level in over three years, driven by China's production capacity constraints and rising demand in key markets. London Metal Exchange aluminum futures reached $3,008 per tonne as of January 2026.

title: China's Alumina Market: Persistent Supply Surplus Amid Production Adjustments in December 2025 and January 2026 Outlook
summary: The article reports that China's alumina output is forecast to edge down to about 7.6 million tonnes in January 2026, with daily production slightly lower than in December as some refineries trim operating rates.[2] Despite the reduction, a persistent supply surplus is expected, with inventories staying relatively high and keeping alumina prices under pressure in the near term.[2]

title: Aluminium alloy futures fluctuate at highs, and short-term macro tailwinds boost the market
summary: This report notes that aluminium alloy futures in China have been fluctuating at relatively high levels, supported by macroeconomic tailwinds and firm cost support.[3] SHFE data show total registered cast aluminium alloy warrant volumes around 69,922 tonnes as of January 9, 2026, indicating ample exchange stocks even as prices resume an upward trend.[3]

title: Alcoa, Ball and Unilever debut carbon-free aluminium aerosol packaging
summary: Alcoa, Ball Corporation and Unilever announced what they describe as the first-ever aerosol can made with 50% ELYSIS carbon-free primary aluminium and 50% post-consumer recycled content, launched ahead of COP30. The ELYSIS smelting process replaces carbon anodes with inert materials so that oxygen, rather than CO₂, is emitted, enabling one of the lowest‑carbon aluminium packaging solutions currently available for personal and home care products.[1]

title: CES Innovation Awards 2026 Honoree: Portable SSD T7 Resurrected with 100% recycled aluminum enclosure
summary: Samsung detailed its CES 2026 Innovation Awards honoree, the Portable SSD T7 Resurrected, which features an enclosure made from 100% recycled aluminum sourced from smartphone production scrap and uses recycled paper packaging. The company frames the device as a flagship example of circular design, enabled by cross‑division collaboration, and a starting point for a broader ecosystem that reuses aluminum and other waste materials across multiple product categories.[5]

title: Steel Prices in the Second Week of January 2026
summary: The Arab Iron and Steel Union reports that global iron and steel markets showed relative **price stability** in the second week of January 2026, with only limited price movements.[6] The update notes that both iron ore and finished steel products traded in a narrow range, indicating a tentative balance between supply and demand in major regions.[6]

title: Steel - Price, News and Market Data
summary: Benchmark Chinese steel (rebar) prices hovered above **CNY 3,120 per ton**, near a multi‑month high as of January 9, 2026, supported by expectations of fresh economic stimulus in China.[1] Trading Economics notes that prices have risen about 1.7% over the past month but remain slightly below year‑earlier levels, with the People’s Bank of China signaling easier monetary policy that underpins the demand outlook.[1]

title: HRC Steel Hits Multi‑Month High as 2026 Begins
summary: US hot‑rolled coil (HRC) steel prices rose to **around 940 USD/ton** on January 9, 2026, extending a rally that has lifted values more than 30% compared with the same period a year earlier.[2] Trading Economics highlights that HRC recently touched its highest level since April 2025, reflecting tighter supply and firmer demand in flat steel markets.[2]

title: U.S. crude steel production recorded an increase on an annual basis in the week ending January 3, 2026
summary: According to American Iron and Steel Institute (AISI) data, U.S. crude steel production reached 1,704,000 net tons in the week ending January 3, 2026, up 1.4% from 1,680,000 net tons in the same week a year earlier.[1] Capacity utilization was 74.4%, slightly below 75.6% a year ago, while production rose 0.5% from the previous week’s 1,695,000 net tons and regional output was led by the South with 759,000 net tons.[1]

title: PPC Japan Copper Premium Hits Record High, LME Copper Fluctuated and Closed Higher on Friday
summary: LME copper closed at $12,965.5/mt on Friday with a 2.07% gain, fluctuating between $12,907/mt and $13,039/mt during the session. Pan Pacific Copper proposed a record copper premium of $330/mt for Japanese customers in 2026, more than three times the 2025 level of $88, reflecting tight market supply and demand fundamentals.

title: Copper prices near all-time high: Structural shift or speculative spike
summary: MCX January 2026 copper futures jumped over 1.3% to Rs 1330.45 per kg, nearing lifetime highs as copper prices continue their rally.

title: Copper price hits record $13000/t as rally continues
summary: LME cash copper reached a record high of almost $13,300/t on January 6, 2026, marking the first time the price pushed above $13,000/t as the rally continues.

title: Viewpoint: US copper faces uncertain 2026 outlook
summary: US copper prices are expected to remain volatile in 2026 due to multiple factors including Chinese demand, supply constraints, and tariff uncertainty. Market participants forecast a strong first half of 2026, with Goldman Sachs expecting average copper prices of $5.17/lb compared to $4.82/lb in 2025, driven by insufficient mine output and AI-related infrastructure demand.

title: Five Copper Miners Leading the Commodity Rally as Producers Post Explosive Monthly Returns
summary: Copper miners and producers have posted double-digit gains as investors position for infrastructure spending and energy transition demand. Companies like Freeport-McMoRan surged 26.2% over the past month, with director buying signaling confidence in continued copper demand from AI infrastructure and Trump's housing initiatives.

title: Nickel falls from 19-month peak as metals rally pauses
summary: Nickel prices eased after briefly touching a 19‑month high near $18,800 per ton, as the recent broad rally in base metals paused.[3] The earlier surge was driven by concerns over reduced output from Indonesia and strong investment flows into Chinese metals markets, but three‑month LME nickel was last quoted around $18,370 per ton alongside declines in copper, aluminum, zinc, and lead.[3]

title: Nickel gluts to zinc deficits: LME shadow stocks tell the story
summary: LME shadow stock data show a pronounced contrast between nickel oversupply and zinc tightness, highlighting how off‑warrant inventories shape apparent market balance.[9] The article notes that three‑month nickel recently spiked to a 19‑month high of $18,800 per ton before retreating to $17,895, underscoring how supply‑risk headlines can trigger sharp but volatile price moves in an otherwise well‑supplied nickel market.[9]

title: Global Nickel Market Recalibrates After Explosive Trading Week
summary: After a week of extreme price swings, three‑month LME nickel is hovering near US$17,900 per metric ton, recovering from a mid‑week slump while still up significantly from December levels.[7] Analysts cited by Nasdaq say the market is reassessing Indonesia‑related supply risks and speculative flows, with traders watching whether recent double‑digit intraday gains will give way to consolidation or further spikes.[7]

title: Pressure for Indonesian quota U-turn is a risk for nickel price rally
summary: Indonesia, which accounts for about 70% of global nickel production, has pushed nickel prices to 19‑month highs by planning cuts to mining quotas, but analysts warn there is strong industry pressure for the government to reverse course.[4] Many new Indonesian nickel projects are due to come onstream in the second half of the year, and producers may seek higher quotas later, which could lift output and cap further price gains.[4]

title: Nickel price tumbles 4.12% as Indonesia's output remains unclear
summary: Nickel prices on the London Metal Exchange fell more than 4% from their recent peak as uncertainty persisted over Indonesia’s 2026 production plans and output quotas.[8] Market participants are reassessing expectations for Indonesian supply, with ambiguity over approved mining volumes creating volatility in both price direction and capacity outlook.[8]

title: Global nickel market recalibrates after explosive trading week
summary: Nickel prices stabilized after a highly volatile week in which futures surged to more than two‑year highs and then retreated as traders reassessed the impact of Indonesia’s proposed output cuts.[7] The article details how expectations for reduced Indonesian production, combined with changing views on demand from stainless steel and batteries, are forcing the market to recalibrate supply and capacity assumptions.[7]

title: Nickel – Price, news and Indonesian output cuts
summary: Nickel futures recently hit around $18,500 per tonne, the highest in over two years, supported by concerns over supply from Indonesia after Jakarta proposed a 34% reduction in nickel output in its 2026 budget.[1] The piece notes that Indonesia’s move, aimed at addressing oversupply and declining ore grades, could significantly tighten global production capacity even as prices remain volatile.[1]

title: Talon Metals completes acquisition of Eagle Mine and Humboldt Mill, creating a multi‑asset U.S. nickel‑copper company
summary: Talon Metals has closed its acquisition of Lundin Mining’s Eagle Mine and Humboldt Mill operations in the U.S., forming a multi‑asset nickel‑copper company with an expanded domestic production base.[6] The company plans to extend mine life at Eagle, accelerate exploration in Michigan and Minnesota, and advance the Tamarack Nickel‑Copper Project and a planned battery minerals processing facility, effectively increasing future U.S. nickel capacity.[6]

title: TECH Project high-grade nickel is primed to fuel the global green transition
summary: Innovation News Network reports on Queensland Pacific Metals’ TECH Project in Australia, which aims to become a major source of high‑grade, ethically derived nickel for electric vehicle and energy‑storage supply chains.[1] The project uses the DNi Process, an extraction technology designed to recycle more than 98% of nitric acid, avoid tailings dams, minimize waste, and ultimately operate as a carbon‑negative, sustainable facility.[1]

title: Nickel Supply Woes: Innovations Steering a Sustainable EV Future
summary: CarbonCredits.com analyzes how high‑nickel NMC batteries are driving nickel demand and examines technological and supply‑chain innovations to keep EV growth sustainable.[2] The article highlights alternative chemistries like LFP and sodium‑ion, material innovation toward low‑nickel or nickel‑free batteries, and advanced recycling to create a more circular, resilient nickel supply chain.[2]

title: Nickel's role in the future of safer electric vehicle batteries
summary: Researchers from the University of Texas at Austin and Argonne National Laboratory have conducted an extensive study on high‑nickel cathodes for EV batteries, detailing how nickel’s high energy density can be harnessed while addressing safety and stability challenges.[3] By mapping critical states of charge and understanding metal‑oxygen bond strength and surface reactivity, the work proposes guidelines for safer, more efficient nickel‑rich battery designs that support the clean‑energy transition.[3]

title: Hydrogen to decarbonize steel: first trial launched in Italy
summary: Tenaris, together with Snam and Tenova, has launched the first industrial trial in Italy to use hydrogen at a steel plant, aiming to decarbonize steel processing. The six‑month test at Tenaris’s Dalmine mill in Bergamo will use on‑site produced hydrogen in a Tenova burner to heat steel for hot‑rolling seamless pipes, while developing safety guidelines and procedures to cut CO₂ emissions in hard‑to‑abate sectors.[1]

title: Advancing power generation: Tenaris in dialogue with Macchi at Hydrogen Expo 2025
summary: At Hydrogen Expo 2025 in Piacenza, Italy, Tenaris highlighted its steel tube solutions for high‑performance, low‑emission power generation in a panel with boiler maker Macchi. The company emphasized long‑term collaboration with Sofinter Group, investments in advanced manufacturing (including high‑alloy steels) and products like Thor 115 to support efficiency and environmental performance in combined‑cycle plants.[2]

title: Tenaris in Italy achieves ASME certification for the supply of materials for the nuclear sector
summary: Tenaris’s Dalmine seamless steel pipe mill in Italy has obtained ASME III accreditation to supply certified materials for nuclear facilities. This certification positions Tenaris to serve both new‑build and maintenance nuclear projects globally, aligning with growing use of nuclear as a low‑carbon, dispatchable energy source.[3]

title: Copper Cables: Antitrust Launches Investigation into Alleged Cartel – Prysmian and Nexans Down on the Stock Exchange
summary: Italy’s antitrust authority (AGCM) has opened an investigation into several major low‑voltage copper cable manufacturers in Italy, including Prysmian Cavi e Sistemi Italia, over alleged price‑fixing conduct dating back to 2005.[2] The probe, still at an early stage, triggered share price declines for Prysmian and Nexans, though analysts currently expect only a negligible impact on Prysmian given that the Italian low‑voltage copper cable market represents less than 3% of its revenues.[2]
